title: Thursday, 8th February, 2018
bodyHTML:
11:03 am
BE11:03am

How. Is. It. Only. Thursday?

rwl Morning all!
Gross Loydman morning
wayneJ Morning
Grouchmonkey Morning
BE11:03am

Anyway, hello. Welcome. Hi. This is Markets Live, FT Alphaville's etc.

Blank canvas good morning all
wayneJ Was yesterday President's day?
BE11:03am

Have a picture. Actually, have a postcard.

Soundbuy Morning
LJ morning all
Manxish Morning
11:03 am
BE11:04am

MnM Manana
BE11:04am

Yeah, all of that.

GBKrona Hola
wayneJ Surely is disingenuous to use the medium of the postcard but then post it electronically and not have a stamp? Like kicking sand in the face......
A. M. (nice ink)
BE11:05am

Here at Markets Live we embrace imprecision by getting a lot of the numbers wrong and treat surprises as a mystery by not reading stuff before we cut and paste it.

#REF! @wayneJ yeah I thought that too
rwl "Embrace Imprescision " - can be painful :)
11:05 am
BE11:06am

Anyway, it's a big bunch of results today so let's plough into them.

undefined
BE11:06am

Oh -- top line first. Down.

#REF! pushing my luck possibly, but NANO grey?
Grouchmonkey Please lets not talk about artificial hips. Just had breakfast.
11:07 am
BE11:07am

We're doing the volatility cluster thing right now. ~1% up or down each day. Today it's down.

BE11:07am

(@#Ref! the hell's NANO?)

BE11:08am

Sophos is as good a place to begin as anywhere, right?

11:08 am
Sophos Group PLC (SOPH:LSE): Last: 551.50, down 70 (-11.26%), High: 572.50, Low: 509.50, Volume: 4.26m
#REF! oh sorry Nanoco, little aim stock, I have embraced the matrix and speak only in RIC codes.
BE11:08am

Billings look bad year on year.

#REF! @BE I took your lead and "embraced imprescision" with my post :)
BE11:08am

As in, turned negative.

red re SOPH it didnt really correct with tech falls did it
wayneJ @Ref - is this Dow that they are talking about?
11:09 am
BE11:09am

Which the company blames on InterceptX -- malware and ransomware detection, that kind of thing -- being launched a year ago.

BE11:10am

That's not entirely convincing though, because Sophos is a repeat business business. Once you get into the blood of your customer's IT system, you're there for good.

BE11:11am

It also revives all those old concerns we have voiced here about Sophos's preference to report earnings in a nonstandard format.

#REF! @wayneJ who knows, iirc thewy still have an agreement with Dow, exclusive in Korea. But they paid themselves out of the exclusive dow agreement because the orders didn't materilise in big enough volumes
wayneJ Sophos gets 'into the blood' - makes it sound like a virus......I thought it was an ANTI-virus co?
#REF! hard to predict what impact it will have on revenues, but won't take much to change the dial (trailing
11:12 am
BE11:12am

As in, Cash ebitda. I've had analysts explain to me with the patience of primary school teachers how it's entirely fine and gives a better view of actual cash performance, but I'm still not 100%.

BE11:13am

Anyway, here's UBS with the summary of where we are.

BE11:13am

Q: How did the results compare vs expectations?
A: Billings grew 14% c/c in Q3 to $195m (cons. $200m). Within this, Enduser grew 22% and Network 10%. While Enduser slowed from H1's 41%, mgt notes it lapped Intercept X's launch. It was also in-line with our estimate. We had hoped for a better Network result given the October launch of XG Firewall v17, although mgt describes customers' reaction as "very positive". Cash EBITDA of $47m and unlevered FCF of $18m were down $1-2m y/y and well-short of cons. but cost seasonality has in the past been very variable: Mgt notes "planned investment in recent new product releases" (XG and the new Intercept X) hit. Last year, marketing investments were loaded in Q4

11:13 am
BE11:14am

Q: Has the company's outlook/guidance changed?
A: The deceleration in Enduser is noteworthy and Q4 comps are tougher, but after 21% YTD billings growth, mgt is confident of hitting its 20-22% target for the year and 50-100bp of EBITDA margin expansion (ytd -120bp). It implies in Q4 18-25% growth and margins of 31.6-32.9% margins (+510-640bp y/y). Cons. is currently looking for 19% growth to $224m and cash EBITDA at $60m/26.9%. Guidance implies $222-235m and $70-77m given the cost skew to Q3.

BE11:14am

(@WayneJ: perhaps consider it IT immunotherapy. Though they prefer to talk about deep learning and that kind of buzzword guff.)

Otter Hello internet friends
BE11:15am

Is it a surprise, tho? UBS says not.

11:14 am
BE11:15am

Some weakness is likely, but the tougher H2 Enduser comparatives should have been anticipated and cost seasonality has been very varied historically we note.

wayneJ @BE - ah - the Gilead of the IT world.....
BE11:16am

Numis -- the excellent David Toms and Will Wallis -- say yes.

Stateless My view is that all antivirus companies on personal and network computers are useless. Website, firewalls, security certification and not clicking on dodgey links is perfectly fine as virus protection.
BE11:16am

The key issue for us is why billings have slowed so much in Q3
when there is a benefit of c.400-500bp from a bigger renewals book. Management point to a tough comp (InterceptX was launched at the start of the comparator Q3-17) but we are a little surprised that the renewals book benefit doesn't seem to have offset much of this.

Grouchmonkey Didn't Sophos management slot quite a few shares arfter earlier predicting what a great quarter this was going to be?
#REF! @stateless fine for you maybe but if enterprises always have one or more weak links who will click on the link. Users are the problem in security
11:17 am
BE11:17am

Numis notes that it's a small miss quite soon after share sales by Apax and a load of directors, which never looks great.

Miss Piggy Gyrations in equities but in bonds, ust 10s 2s spread stable. Good morning.
BE11:18am

Planned investment means Cash EBITDA and FCF both look very Q4 skewed, although this is slightly less so than last year, and the company does have a good track record of rapid returns from its expenditure so we are confident that this is deliverable. Overall however, the slowdown in billings is a little worrisome, particularly given the renewals tailwind in the quarter, but probably more significantly, the beat-and-raise pattern at Sophos looks to be, at least temporarily, on hold for now, as is our recommendation.

BE11:19am

We can also quote Neil Campling, now of Mirabaud. "Just insane" he says, about the 18% price dump early on.

11:19 am
BE11:19am

Technically yes Q3 billings is slower than H1 but it's inline with guidance (and a tough comp due to product launch timing anniversary) and Q4 is set up for a beat because the new flagship product was launched in Jan (after the end of Q3) and we have GDPR ahead too. Reason for weakness probably due to unlevered FCF of $22.2M in Q3 which c.20% below consensus, but this is due to the timing of investment in new product releases. And, ironically, these same new product releases will likely drive a very strong Q4 billings #.

BE11:19am

We use Sophos at the FT, incidentally.

#REF! Apologies I seemingly cannot type a coherent sentence today
BE11:21am

And apologies as I go off into anecdote. A week or so I downloaded a Chrome extension for auto refreshing. Just the top result that turned up in the search.

rwl re SOPH - Hargreaves site says it has a PE of 101 - not sure how calculated !
11:21 am
BE11:22am

But on installation, Chrome immediately identified it as dodgy and terminated it.

rw42 @Stateless - maybe true if you use perfect adblockers or never browse the internet. IMO risk these days is a dodgy advert JS exploit rather than a numpty clicking a bad link!
BE11:22am

Then, about an hour later I had two guys from IT turn up at my desk telling me they'd identified a bitcoin miner operating on my PC.

FATDAZ @BE would imagine there are many of those kicking about
Shinshin @BE - result! An easy $12k..no $8k...no $9k...
BE11:23am

I got told off for installing stuff without asking them, of course. But ever since, about once or twice a day, I get a little Sophos window in the corner telling me it's torched a bitcoin miner in the background.

Miss Piggy Carney up
Kadhim Shubber FT Might be an idea to stop running all those bitcoin miners then byrce
11:24 am
BE11:24am

Which .... is nice? I guess? Anyway, I'm not sure where this anecdote is going other than to say, "hey here's a thing."

BE11:24am

It needs a better ending. I'll workshop it.

undefined
wayneJ Makes one wonder what other BOTS have been downloaded onto BE's machine........perhaps the ROTR is undertaking an advanced Turning test with the BE BOT??
11:24 am
BE11:25am

Then, of course, there's TalkTalk.

Talktalk Telecom Group PLC (TALK:LSE): Last: 107.40, down 12.3 (-10.28%), High: 115.50, Low: 98.65, Volume: 8.10m
BE11:25am

It's going to lay fibre in front of 3m homes!

Manumission GSK have done well since the results

Stateless @Rw42 fair point. I don't tend to "browse" the web. I tend to know where im going.
TheManwithaLongChin mining alphachain Shirley
rw42 Which means your computer is still pwned - sophos is detecting the miner, not the process which is launching the miner. Nuke the PC from orbit!
Miss Piggy BryceCoin
11:25 am

Or, rather, it's going to pay £100m to take a 20 per cent stake in an independent company that'll do that.

December69 @BE why do they need to take a stake in any company? Haven't they heard of contractors?
rw42 @Stateless - these days i consider that irrelevant. Any site with adverts that aren't blocked is a risk the way ads are farmed out to exchanges, and the best you'll get from them is an 'oops, sorry' if someone manages to get an exploit past their checks!
GBKrona Gosh - TALK going to be solution for fibre in UK, even though it has little cash - all through a JV. Wonder what could possibly go wrong?

The other £100m -- which it's raising as I type, probably at a price of about 104p and we're getting all the usual crap about oversubscription and such -- is disappearing into debt.

BE11:27am

Plus we get a "temporary" dividend cut.

rwl @Miss Piggy - and Brye Ico : BIKO for short :)
11:27 am

erlkin anyone have thoughts on Gold and how it has been falling thru volatility spike?.....

I haven't looked closely at this by the way, ROTR, so can you help. How is Talktalk able to do a cashbox placing for 19.99% of share capital?

11:29 am

BE11:30am

Is it because the founders and directors are kicking in up to £40m? Can't see why that would change anything.

BE11:30am

Anyway, let me cut to Citi to summarise how awful the figures are.

11:30 am
BE11:30am

The company has again cut EBITDA guidance for FY18 (to £230-245m excl MVNO costs of £10-15m vs c.£270m previously) but on better net adds. It has introduced guidance of +15% yoy for EBITDA in FY19. TalkTalk is hopeful that it has sufficient support from shareholders to get the placing in full but there is a risk that the 19.99% binds if the share price falls leaving a little short. It is cutting the dividend to 2.5p from the planned 7.5p (FY19 now 4.0p, final to be 1.5p).

alewis2005 looking forward to talktalk getting punished by GDPR
BE11:31am

We estimate that with the £100m from the capital raise that is not earmarked for the FTTP project, c.£43m in savings from the FY18 final and FY19 interim dividends (allowing for dilution) and FY19 capex at £110m (Citi: £123m) FY19 net debt/EBITDA would be 2.3x vs our forecast of 2.9x (based on guidance EBITDA midpoint of £265m post MVNO costs vs Citi £270m). This should be enough, in our view, if the placing is completed.

BE11:32am

As to this fibre thing .......

wayneJ Why is TalkTalk insistent that they are going to put fibre down the front of houses - at our old house the back of the house was much preferable? :-)
Miss Piggy Never mind gold, oil's march to 70 has been arrested
red any views on BoE super thursday?
11:32 am
BE11:33am

M&G leading a potential equity investment of up to £500m, plus up to £1bn in debt, to put fibre down in front of 3m premises in UK mid-sized towns and cities.

wayneJ Of course, on a serious note, Talk Talk, Hyperoptic, Virgin Media and BT all use the same GIS systems and the same rationale - so some houses in the UK will get 5 bits of fibre running down the front and others none at all...
wayneJ Won't occur to any of them that they ought to put fibre where others won't.
BE11:34am

The £100m equity contribution TalkTalk fronts up is to be paid over the next 5 years. Which I guess is a positive when it's scrapped in 2019. There'll be another £80m or so to kick into the debt pit.

BE11:34am

Numis:

GBKrona @WayneJ - I thought TALK has explicitly stated second-Tier cities, as lower competition there

[W]e think the announcement that TALK/M&G will build 3m FTTP infrastructure seems unlikely to become much more than a press release for a few quarters yet. Also, this investment will become very high risk if SKY chooses not to wholesale the TALK/M&G network. We place our rating and TP Under Review

The Sky angle's interesting, right?

wayneJ @GBK - I meant at an individual street level - eg our street never gets fibre because of the way it is structured but the GIS systems fail to note that there is already a duct down one side and a grass verge down the other and the probability of signup and taking max package is very high; yet about 1/2 mile away there is fibre passing some higher density housing but due to all kinds of reasons the ROI is probably very low (consider eg not revenue but cost of collection)

I mean, we can't even say with any certainty who's going to own Sky by this time next year.

Soundbuy Cost overruns down the line then............??

In April 2014, during the event to discuss the formation of the CITY/TALK/SKY JV in York, TALK’s CEO said “we can do this fundamentally because of the combined scale of Sky and TalkTalk. That's fundamentally what makes it economically viable to build FTTP”. We estimate the following broadband market shares currently: BT (36%), SKY (24%), VMED (20%), TALK (16%; of which 4% is due to wholesale customers), Other (4%).

Stevie Ashland/Croda?

11:40 am

Anyway, it's just archaeology now. Here's Jefferies.

BE11:46am

[W]e believe the news represents mostly confirmation of a biding interest tempered by capital discipline, rather than evidence Croda is off on an adventure or Ashland lacks confidence in its stand-alone value proposition.

wayneJ Hi Deccy.
11:46 am
BE11:47am

In our standard (i.e. Procrustean) LBO model (20% target IRR, synergies 5% of sales, IPO @ 11x), fair value for Ashland is pegged at $84. In our acquisition benchmark model, Croda could pay ~$81/share in an all-stock deal and achieve a FY3 ROIC comparable to a buyback, which would rise to ~$92 for a 5% ROIC, similar to what BASF (BAS GR, Hold) paid for Chemetall or Air Liquide (AI FP, Buy) for Airgas. On an $81/share offer, before adjusting for capital structure, we estimate FCF/share accretion would have been ~37%, and EPS accretion before deal amortization ~25%.

Why Walk? For Croda shareholders, confirmation of a disciplined approach to capital allocation protects the valuation multiple. Pro-forma leverage of 3.5x would be manageable, in our view, given a combined 15% FCF/sales, but equity dilution would have been stiff, and at $92/share (28% control premium), for example, Croda shareholders would have needed to believe Ashland synergies would be capitalized at 15x to expect an equitable split in synergy value.

undefined

As to Woodward-Boeing, nothing more to say.

BE11:56am

Here's Barclays.

11:56 am
BE11:56am

Thomas Cook has delivered an encouraging (and slimmed down) Q1 trading release with an underlying EBIT improvement of £10m (mainly due to soft comps from the German Airline Condor, note no company consensus) but the focus will be on the upbeat commentary regarding a discernible shift in demand from the Western Med (where margins are under pressure from input cost inflation) to areas like Turkey/Egypt/Greece where typically Tour Operators generate higher margins. While this is an encouraging trend, it is too early in the year to expect any changes to estimates today. We note too that TCG has flagged that the UK tour operator is seeing bookings +3% and ASPs +6%: reassuring in light of the UK profit warning at FY17 results. TCG trades on a CY18 P/E of 10.5x which is inexpensive in absolute terms but we prefer TUI where earnings volatility is lower and growth is more consistent. We remain EW.

AAAA Muddy Waters Capital LLC is short IQE. IQE is, in our opinion, an egregious accounting manipulator. We adjust downward the company’s reported net income for 2015 and 2016, respectively, by 58.5% and 25.4%. We believe it is reasonable to adjust 1H 2017 net income down by approximately £5 million or 69% to account for likely aggressive capitalization of expenses.
GBKrona thanks @FATDAZ

So ... what are we blaming this on? Margins? Let's go with margins.

11:57 am

Winter bookings are +8%, with -1% ASPs (FY17 update +5% and
+2% respectively), with weaker ASPs reflecting a shift in mix from long-haul to short/medium haul. The programme is 80% sold, similar to last year. Within this, Tour Operator bookings were +1% and ASPs +4%, with UK bookings flat and ASPs +6% reflecting cost inflation. Summer bookings are said to be “encouraging” with 34% of the programme now sold, +3pp yoy. The UK is seeing bookings +3% with ASPs +6%. However this strong performance is offset by the ongoing “significant margin pressure” for Spanish holidays reflecting hotel cost increases and competitive air fares.

FATDAZ @Red of course there must be a boundary somewhere but I wonder if people thought that much about extremes before deployment of these algos & associated strategies ... a few years ago we had a run of 5 and 6 sigma events which I thought was an anomaly now not so sure

and EPS of 11.1p) the stock trades on c11x PE compared to sector peer TUI on c15x. We believe that TCG should trade on a 15%-20% PE discount to TUI. We note the supportive operating environment near term, however remain cautious on the long term industry dynamics and retain our Neutral recommendation.
